#Text=Tacloban
#Text=Tacloban is a city in Eastern Visayas and the capital of the province of Leyte .
#Text=It 's the home of the Pintados Festival , a cultural event in Leyte commemorating the life and culture of the early settlers of Tacloban .
#Text=Tourist Information Centers
#Text=City Tourism Operations Office , Tacloban City Hall .
#Text=City Tourism Information and Assistance Counter , Arrival Area , DZR Airport , San Jose .
#Text=Provincial Tourism Office , Leyte Academic Center , Pawing , Palo , Leyte .
#Text=Department of Tourism Regional Office No. 8 , Magsaysay Blvd , ☏ +63533212048 .
#Text=M - F 9AM-5PM .
#Text=free city map .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Daniel Z. Romualdez Airport ( Tacloban Airport , DZR Airport , TAC ) .
#Text=Formerly a US air base during World War II , it is the main entry point to Leyte ( and Eastern Visayas in general ) by plane .
#Text=Tacloban Airport has one runway which can accommodate small passenger jets like the Airbus A320 family .
#Text=This is badly damaged by Typhoon Haiyan ( Yolanda ) in 2013 , but has been rebuilt , and in 2015 , the airport is the venue of an open-air Mass during Pope Francis ' visit to the Philippines .
#Text=Cebu Pacific flies from Manila using an Airbus A320 jet , while its regional carrier Cebgo flies from Cebu using turboprop aircraft .
#Text=PAL Express flies from Manila and Cebu using jets and turboprops , respectively .
#Text=Philippines AirAsia has flights from Manila or Clark using jets .
#Text=By ferry
#Text=There are no passenger ferries to or from Tacloban , but you can take a bus or van to Ormoc port , Baybay port or Naval port then get a ferry to Cebu City from there .
#Text=By bus
#Text=There are buses going to Manila via Catbalogan , Calbayog , Sorsogon , Legazpi City , Naga , Lucena , and to Davao and Cagayan de Oro via Surigao and Butuan .
#Text=There are small buses going from Tacloban to Naval , Sogod , Maasin , Baybay , and Ormoc .
#Text=Long-distance buses arrive at the Tacloban Bus Terminal , 2 km from downtown .
#Text=Get around
#Text=There are many ways to get from the airport to all over Tacloban City , especially downtown , which is where most of the fun and excitement happens .

#Text=Jeepneys are the cheapest way to get from the airport to downtown and cost an average of ₱10 for a one way trip downtown , for a taxi or pedicab you are looking at ₱50-100 ; if asked for more , then you are being ripped off .
#Text=For visitors not familiar with the city , you hire a tricycle to get to your destination .
#Text=It costs around ₱8 per ride .
#Text=Taxis operate from the airport to any part of the city .
#Text=MLHuillier Taxi have the most cars .
#Text=Taxi service is now available from the hotel to fetch you to the airport or any destination within the city and sub-urban towns around Tacloban at a higher price .
#Text=For pick-up from downtown hotels in Tacloban to the airport , the standard price is ₱250 .
#Text=More than this amount is above the norm .
#Text=Be prepared with the exact amount as drivers may not always have loose change .
#Text=When wanting taxi service at your hotel , ask the front desk , they have contacts with taxi operators and drivers .
#Text=For out-of-city points , prices are negotiable .
#Text=Jeepneys are the cheapest way to travel all around the city .

#Text=Although confusing at first , it may take you a while to adjust to the directions and the naming of the different sections of the city , if in doubt ask a local since everyone is very willing to help .
#Text=When walking around the city , crossing the streets , intersections , observe traffic rules as the city imposes its anti-jaywalking ordinance .
#Text=Some tourists and visitors who are used to the indifference of pedestrians in other cities in the Philippines , Tacloban could be a different place for them .
#Text=The feel of the city is not as urbanized as in other highly urbanized cities in the Philippines .
#Text=So every visitor and locals alike who come from rural towns may mistakenly take for granted traffic rules .
#Text=There is a tendency to disregard the local ordinances .
#Text=See
#Text=Price Mansion , Justice Romualdez Street .
#Text=CAP Building served as the residence and headquarters of General Douglas MacArthur for three months .
#Text=The Redona Residence , T. Claudio Street .
#Text=Official residence of President Sergio Osmena Sr. during the liberation period .
#Text=The Leyte Provincial Capitol , Senator Enage St. The seat of Philippine Commonwealth in 1944 .
#Text=The Philippine-Japan Commemorative Peace Park , Magsaysay Boulevard .
#Text=Stone 's throw away from city hall .
#Text=It was donated by the Tokyo Survivors Associations in honor of soldiers and paramilitary personnel who perished in the area .
#Text=The Maria Kanon Madonna of Peace Shrine , Magsaysay Boulevard .
#Text=Near the city hall .
#Text=Carved out of a rare Miyagi rock and fashioned by Japanese sculptor Shiniche Tani .
#Text=Tacloban City Convention Center , Real Street , Sagkahan District .
#Text=Popularly known as the Astrodome .
#Text=Calvary Hill .
#Text=Larger than life statues of Jesus Christ and other personages , in tableaux , depict Christ 's sacrifice and sufferings .
#Text=Crucified Christ and the Map of Leyte Pilgrim Monument , Magsaysay Boulevard .
#Text=Santo Niño Shrine and Heritage Museum , Real Street .
#Text=Balyuan Amphitheater .
#Text=Boy Scout Monument , Fatima Village .
#Text=World War II Japanese Pillboxes , Baluarte , San Jose .
#Text=Do
#Text=Indoor climbing at Bukid Outdoor Shop , P. Burgos Street .
#Text=San Juanico Bridge .
#Text=It is the longest bridge in the Philippines .
#Text=It connects the city to the third biggest island of the Philippines , Samar .
#Text=The bridge spans 2.14 km and is one of the major tourist spots in the city .
#Text=San Juanico Golf Park and Courtry Club , Cabalawan Hills .
#Text=The People 's Center and Library , Real Street .
#Text=It houses volumes of books from the US and Europe and other countries .
#Text=Events
#Text=Grand
#Text=Santacruzan
#Text=.
#Text=May 30
#Text=Tacloban City Charter Day .
#Text=Balyu-an Rites .
#Text=Subiran Regatta .
#Text=It is a race of one-man native sailboats with outriggers locally called " subiran " along scenic and historic Leyte Gulf .
#Text=The race is done without using a paddle but only skills and techniques to manuever the sail .
#Text=Pintados-Kasadyaan Festival .
#Text=Sangyaw Festival .
#Text=June 29
#Text=Barrio Fiesta .
#Text=Leyte Landing Anniversary , October 20 .
